title: Case Study: Chronic Heel Pain in a Middle-Aged Runner
clinical_history: Mr. William Anderson is a 47-year-old recreational runner who presents with an insidious onset of right heel pain over the last 3 months. He first noticed discomfort in the mornings upon getting out of bed, characterized by a sharp, stabbing pain localized at the bottom of his right heel. The pain diminishes after a few minutes of walking but recurs after periods of rest and intensifies during prolonged activities, particularly after running. He runs approximately 20-25 kilometers per week, and has recently increased his mileage in preparation for a local half marathon. He reports taking over-the-counter painkillers with partial relief. He denies any history of direct trauma to the heel.

nprs.affected_area: plantar aspect of right heel (plantar fascia insertion at calcaneus)
diffuse ache in the right midfoot after longer runs

aggrevating_factors: First steps in the morning, standing after prolonged sitting, running (especially on hard surfaces), walking barefoot on tiles or hardwood floors, prolonged standing (over 45 minutes).
picture: [insert image showing area under the heel and plantar fascia involvement]
easing_factors: Rest, ice application post-activity, wearing cushioned shoes with good arch support, brief stretching of the calf and plantar fascia, over-the-counter NSAIDs.
past_history: No significant heel injuries in the past. Some history of mild intermittent low back discomfort after long car drives, unrelated to current complaint.
medical_history: Medically stable, non-smoker, BMI 28. No diabetes, peripheral vascular disease or inflammatory joint conditions. No prior surgeries.
medications: Ibuprofen 400mg prn (as needed, 2-3 times/week); no regular prescriptions.
personal_history: Works as a real estate agent with variable activity levels â€“ periods of prolonged standing during open houses and significant walking throughout the week. Resides with spouse and two teenage children. He describes himself as generally active with a busy work and family life. Has been more motivated to exercise since his last medical checkup revealed slightly raised cholesterol levels.
imaging: No imaging performed to date; diagnosis based on clinical examination. Will consider musculoskeletal ultrasound if symptoms persist or worsen.
